title: Why is sovereignty important for statehood? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because it is the sine qua non of statehood. Sovereignty means a state can decide who may enter its borders, on any business whatever—and who may not. A state can decide to “levy war, conclude peace, contract alliances, establish commerce, and do all the things and acts which independent states may of right do.” (Thomas Jefferson)

They’re bound up by definition: Oxford Dictionary defines sovereignty as, in general, “supreme power or authority”, and, in particular, “the authority of a state to govern itself or another state”. A State is: “A nation or territory considered as an organised political community under one government.” You can see how the latter requires the former. You can’t have just “one government” without that being the “supreme authority”.
